article.description: Mario Austin had 28 points and nine rebounds in his first game of the season and Mississippi State kept right on winning with him in the lineup, beating Xavier 71-61 Saturday.

related.description: Mario Austin showed no rust -- and plenty of energy -- in his return to the court.
related.linkText: Katz: Austin shows incredible talent, energy levels
related.title: Austin dominant despite layoff
related.headline: Austin dominant despite layoff

images.name: Austin, Mario 020315 inline

related.description: Mississippi State junior forward and Wooden Award preseason all-American Mario Austin was cleared by the NCAA to play Tuesday after missing the No. 22 Bulldogs' first six games of the season.
related.linkText: NCAA clears Austin to play for Mississippi State
related.title: Austin returns in time to battle West, Xavier
related.headline: Austin returns in time to battle West, Xavier

article.headline: Austin quickly back in groove with 28 points
article.linkText: Austin returns with 28 points as MSU rolls
article.story: NEW YORK (AP) -- Mario Austin waited six games before he was allowed to play this season. It didn't take him long at all to know he was back. The 6-foot-9 junior forward had 28 points and nine rebounds in his season debut and Mississippi State (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP) kept right on winning with him in the lineup, beating Xavier (No. 11 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) 71-61 Saturday. "After running up and down the court a few times I felt OK, but then I ran really hard on one break and got the pass, a reward for running hard, and I thought 'I'm back,''' he said. Austin was held out of the Bulldogs' first six games while the NCAA cleared up some questions about his eligibility to play when he was a freshman. He was given the OK to rejoin the team Tuesday, and the Bulldogs (6-1) won their sixth straight as Austin outplayed Xavier's 6-9 forward David West in the matchup of two of the country's better big men. "Obviously, Mario Austin is back,'' Xavier coach Thad Matta said. "What a show he put on today.'' Austin was 12-for-21 from the field, including making his only 3-point attempt, and played 32 minutes. "I didn't come out with any numbers in mind,'' Austin said. "I just wanted to fit in and help us win. It just so happened I took shots and they went in.'' Austin, who averaged 16.1 points and 7.6 rebounds last season, was four points off his career high, set last season against Kentucky. Bulldogs coach Rick Stansbury brought up the 3-pointer, Mississippi State's first points of the second half, as the moment when he knew his star was back. "When he took that 3-pointer I knew he was Mario again,'' Stansbury said with a laugh. Mississippi State, playing for the first time in Madison Square Garden, took control early and then held on over the final two minutes. West, a two-time Atlantic 10 player of the year and the leading vote-getter on the AP's preseason All-America team, had two points in the first half as the Musketeers (5-2) fell behind 33-15. He finished with 13 points, 6.7 below his average, and 17 rebounds -- almost double his 9.5 average. "They did a great job of scouting us,'' West said. "They knew our offense better than we did. We only had 15 points at halftime, we just couldn't get the offense going. They were playing a lot harder than we were.'' It was the first road game of the season for Mississippi State and the second outside Cincinnati for the Musketeers, who have lost them both. Xavier, which had won four straight, lost at Stanford in the second round of the Preseason NIT. "This was our second opportunity against a team from a major conference, and we blew it,'' Matta said. Timmy Bowers added 18 points for the Bulldogs. Dedrick Finn, a freshman guard who entered the game averaging 3.2 points, had 12 for Xavier, all on 3-pointers in the second half. Mississippi State used a 19-2 run in the first half to take a 19-6 lead. The Musketeers missed 13 of 14 shots during the run and turned the ball over six times. The Bulldogs later went on a 10-2 run to take their biggest lead of the half, 23-12. Xavier was 7-for-30 from the field in the first half and missed all eight of its 3-point attempts, while Mississippi State was 15-for-29, including 3-for-7 from beyond the arc. "In the first half the kids stepped another level with Mario back and his presence meant so much defensively,'' Stansbury said. "Our kids did a great job of getting ready for one of the better teams in the country.'' The Musketeers were able to make a game of it in the second half, using a 13-0 run to get to 57-45 with 8:02 to play. They cut the lead to single digits with 5:31 left on a rebound basket by West that made it 61-52, then they got to 67-58 with 1:33 to play on a basket by Lionel Chalmers. But Mississippi State scored four straight points to put it away. Austin is glad the eligibility ordeal is over. "It was hard. Everybody was asking me every day, and I really didn't know,'' he said. "I hung in there and it worked out for me. I'm not bitter. I'm just looking ahead.''
